tweets.text:
A mile of the River Lugg has been bulldozed to destruction.
Bankside trees grubbed out & burnt.
Riverbed scraped out.
Meanders reprofiled.
Disaster for downstream wildlife.
This was an SSSI.
No consent was sought. 
@EnvAgency must surely prosecute this.
RT
https://t.co/cSBhrR2nDW
@EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm Massive hypocrites - the EA is about to bulldoze a chunk of Clifton Ings & Rawcliffe Meadows SSSI in York with plans to destroy more.

@farmerhudson @NaturalEngland @EnvAgency @ForestryComm I understand that all the statutory bodies have endured huge funding cuts resulting in staff losses and we have to ask when these agencies seize being fit for purpose. 

With continuing decline of British wildlife it is becoming urgent to search for effective ways of protection.
We're taking reports of environmental damage to the #SSSI at the #RiverLugg very seriously, and are working with @EnvAgency and @ForestryComm to take immediate action. https://t.co/27DINp3vD7

1/2: IF it is correct that this destruction was permitted by @EnvAgency, then they should only have permitted it having sought the assent of @NaturalEngland (because it's a #SSSI) & it will also have required an assessment under the Habitats Regulations (because it's also an SAC) https://t.co/QdW8F8p2Js

@ianrobertgilmo1 @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm Works by rivers specifically this long, and protected as this is require flood risk permits. The EA will know if one was applied for and granted. Also permissions from NE to work on a sssi would be required. Contractors would have to submit a RAMS for both.

Trees are vital in protecting our rivers.  

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre putting ¬£1.4 million towards funding 15 community projects to plant more trees near rivers and streams.  

Read: https://t.co/Gf0f3pgLNY  
 
#PlantMoreTrees #NationalTreeWeek #TogetherForOurPlanet https://t.co/9ILpU5ivbX

urls.title: Police move in after Herefordshire river bulldozed and straightened
urls.description: Witness describes damage to mile-long stretch of Lugg as egregious act of ‚Äòecological vandalism‚Äô

@tveitdal @SalmonTroutCons @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm @EnvAgency Why on earth would someone want to do this?
@CouncilCapers @Feargal_Sharkey @EnvAgency They need to prosecute. If anything to allow them to recover the cost of fixing this from the person who did it, and deter others.

tweets.text: We're mounting a wide-ranging investigation into reports of damage to the #RiverLugg, which is protected through SSSI status. We're treating this very seriously, working with @NaturalEngland & @ForestryComm who have taken immediate action to prevent any further works at the site. https://t.co/bvhnTETfal

@KeasdenKate Is impacted section itself SAC? If so the UK government itself could be prosecuted, potentially failing to conduct HRA of any consents and also under Regulation 3(2) for failing to take appropriate steps to avoid deterioration of a Natura 2000 Site. Nudges and winks by @EnvAgency

@AmiesPhilip @KeasdenKate @EnvAgency Clear case for prosecutions then. The Lugg dredging is a defining test case, @pow_rebecca  - is this government contemptuous of international wildlife law, or not?

tweets.text: @GarethTrewick @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm Thanks I just saw an item about that. His village were frustrated by the @EnvAgency 's lack of action. Sad to see the trees go but - can we blame him?

Another miserable river scrape down over c. 40 m of bank leading to mass non-natural soil erosion & habitat loss on the Great Ouse. Don't expect this to be good for spawning barbel @EnvAgency https://t.co/5RIOzVVXcc

2/2: So many questions to be answered - & IF this was done with the agreement of either/both - a text book example of exactly why we need an independent & robust watchdog with adequate recourse to legal challenge - something that the #EnvironmentBill looks set to fail to deliver

Lovin' this re-wiggling farmer, he can farm my banks anytime. We have heroics in these parts too with @Stumpupfortrees doing some great work to get my summer water to me. Investment in the future. Take note @NatResWales, @EnvAgency, @futuregencymru  What good farmers do. https://t.co/WaIG2rDTbS

@EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm Surely there is a ‚Äúcode of practice‚Äù that covers all groundwork‚Äôs along river banks that contractors must follow?

6000 trees planted this last week in this little valley - and about another 10,000 to go in on our land in the New Year - no impact on productivity, as all at margins, in low productivity bits and in dykes - more than made up for with better grazing management https://t.co/Mni1dhI3Sx

urls.title: Guest blog - How nature dies by Alistair Gammell - Mark Avery
urls.description: Alistair Gammell worked for RSPB for 40 years and was closely involved in the drafting of the Birds and Habitats Directives and for growing RSPB‚Äôs international work. He was RSPB‚Äôs first International Director and retired from RSPB in 2009. He then worked to successfully establish large scale fully protected marine reserves in the seas around the British Indian Ocean Territory and Pitcairn Island. He is a passionate nature conservationist and fly fisherman (alistairgammell@yahoo.co.uk) Oughton Head is a
